awd_titl_txt: RoL: EAGER: DESYN-C3: Using synthetic energy-harvesting materials at the cell surface to reduce low potential ferredoxins within the cytosol for metabolic applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Cells utilize many chemical sources of energy. Photosynthetic cells can use sunlight to create chemical bonds that store energy. That energy is used to shuttle electrons around the cell, driving reactions. Despite that, cells cannot utilize external sources of electrical energy directly. If they could utilize electricity as a power source, that would greatly reduce the burden on the cell to create energy on site, freeing it to be directed to more productive activities. This project is an attempt to create a cellular interface that allows that to happen. The external power source will be electricity generated by solar panels. The electricity will drive the production of an amino acid.  Graduate students and undergraduates will be trained in advanced bioelectronics research techniques. 


The goal of this project is to build a modular cell-material interface that couples external electrical energy sources to the reduction of ferredoxins. The material side of the interface will enable attachment to a range of energy harvesting devices. The cell side will facilitate the transport of  low potential electrons across the cell membrane to a ferredoxin, which will then be used to enhance the production of a reduced metabolite, the amino acid cysteine. The first objective is to engineer efficient electron transfer across the membrane. A high-throughput selection will be used to couple the growth of Escherichia coli to the electron cycling efficiency of low potential ferredoxin (Fd) electron carriers. The second objective is to build a biocompatible material (an organic electrode) that functions as a cell-surface coupling module. Diffusible mediators will be incorporated into the electrode and the effectiveness of organic phospholipids in mediating long-range electron transfer will be examined. The final objective is to use biological-organic hybrids to increase metabolic pathway yields and characterize electron transfer efficiencies.  The interfaces arising from this project will be modular, and potentially useful in powering natural and synthetic cell processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project was to establish rules and methods for programming electron (e-) transfer from advanced materials that harvest or transport energy and move it across the cell wall into defined protein e- carriers within the cell and can be used for the cellular production of useful biomolecules. Our work uses methods of both synthetic biology and materials development to achieve efficient e- transfer across the cell/materials interface at a low potential and generate more efficient devices for chemical production.  The research project was initiated in three laboratories focused on low-potential protein electron carriers and intracellular monitoring; organic electron conducting materials and processes for forming an effective cell-material interface; and constructing strains that would show the effects of incoming electrons on biosynthesis of an amino acid. 

 

We made scientific progress on all fronts, specifically:  We have purified recombinant ferredoxins, sulfite reductase, and FNR and investigated reduction of mediators. We cataloged and developed mediator targets for protein design and the creation of ferredoxin-mediator reductases in cells. We developed a novel method for attachment of electrogenic cells to appropriately derivatized electronic surfaces.  We developed an effective thin film coating that enhanced current densities by a factor of 170 relative to unmodified electrodes, and produced thick, porous, and conductive electrode coatings that can encapsulate bacteria and further enhance current densities. We made advances in forming stable, conductive cell-material interfaces for microbial electronics: Stability in aqueous environment for more than 12 days was measured. We developed a transistor-based device for amplifying currents due to extracellular electron transfer and generate more sensitive microbial biosensors that have been used in proof-of-principle devices and sensors. Significant improvement in biotic current density was made. The improvement we achieved in this study is among the highest reported for microbial electrochemical systems using either two-dimensional or three-dimensional electrodes.  We also devised a simple method for fabrication of patterned microbial bioelectronics by depositing two different microbial strains at distinct regions on the same substrate. We investigated 3D printing of a multilayered, conductive, double-network hydrogel mesh to provide a way to manufacture complex electrode structures and device architectures to enhance device performance. A test strain was developed for interfacing with the electronic component to examine effects of electrode action on cell productivity of an amino acid.

Training and education efforts included: Mentoring 6 graduate students, 4 postdoctoral researchers, and 2 undergraduates who participated in the research and learned skills needed to pursue diverse STEM careers that require advanced scientific training. Some mentored undergraduates participated in the NSF-supported summer program in Bionetworks and two graduate students participated in the new NSF-funded graduate training program in Bioelectronics.

Three papers were published with another manuscript under review and one is currently being drafted for submission. Students and faculty presented the findings at scientific meetings. We have pursued a variety of opportunities for continued funding from federal agencies. The Pis Coordinated the first Gordon Research Conference on Bioelectronics, chaired by Verduzco and Silberg. The PIs also coordinated and chaired the De Lange Major Conference on Bioelectronics.

 


Last Modified: 12/01/2021
Modified by: George N Bennett
